node.text:
Dr. Jazmine McCoy of @themompsychologist offers tangible tips for parents of young children who want to actively raise them to be anti-racist. Check out more resources at @themompsychologist and on her YouTube channel! Thank you Dr. Jazmine for your willingness to partner with us to offer extremely valuable education on this important topic ❤️❤️❤️
•
Don’t forget to tag a parent who is learning, growing and aiming to put in the work to change the future for all our children.
•
Our 100% fundraiser sale on our online courses ends tonight {Saturday} at 11:59 PM EST. All sales made since we launched this sale Thursday night will benefit @appetiteforchange. Please head back one slide for more info.
•
We will resume feeding content on Sunday. Later today in our stories we will share how we hope to continue to actively evolve as a company and as individuals in working toward anti-racism.

node.title: Raising Anti-Racist Children: Starting the Conversation

node.text:
Wait for it…
•
Tell us how your kid has punked you recently ⬇️⬇️⬇️
•
Via @thedad

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 30, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people standing and text.

node.text:
This beautiful image by @feliciasaundersphoto shared a few years ago captures what’s most important when feeding your baby: knowing what’s best for your child {and family}, getting the support that you need and feeding with love 🥰
•
Tell us your early feeding story ⬇️❤️, and tag a friend who would love this breathtaking image.
•
Breastfeeding.
Formula feeding.
Combo feeding.
Exclusive pumping. 
Breastfeeding a toddler. 
Tube feeding.
Donor milk feeding.
TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition).
•
All babies need different things, and all families need support in reaching their own personal feeding goals. 
•
If you’re struggling in your milk feeding journey, please seek help. Talk to your provider. There are professionals and support groups and people out there who want to help you.
•
However your journey goes...know that you’re making the best decisions for your child, and nobody can judge that.
•
➡️➡️ Supporting another family in making their best decision does not negate your decision or experience. It doesn’t take away from the benefits of the method you chose (or that which was chosen for you). It simply means that we are different. Yes, we need more breastfeeding normalization and education and support...much more support. Yes, breastfeeding can be a beautiful and wonderful thing for many people...and so can formula feeding, tube feeding, combo feeding....We need more love, less judgment.
•
Maybe one day this image can be expanded upon to represent even more feeding modalities, more diversity, more ways in which we are different but still want the same thing: thriving, happy babies.
•
If we approach each other with understanding and respect as parents, maybe we’ll find that we’re not so different after all ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'More likely to drink it: More likely to dump it everywhere: feedinglittles'.

node.text:
If the cup is too full, toddlers are more prone to pouring it alllllll over the place. Yay 😂🙄
•
This post is inspired by our team member’s Leah’s 2-year-old. They have been staying with grandparents this summer, and suddenly the once-proficient cup user Livi started dumping out her cup every chance she got. 
•
Curious, Leah asked her why. “It’s too full, mama.” 
•
Kids can get easily visually overwhelmed at mealtime. We see this all the time with food - when we start with very small amounts on the plate, they’re oftentimes much more likely to try it. It’s much less overwhelming for an apprehensive eater.
•
Well…as Livi taught us this week…same goes for cups. If your tot keeps dumping them everywhere, try less water.
•
We have a blog post all about how to help your kiddo learn to use an open cup and straw cup. Click our link in bio to check it out. They’ll definitely need assistance when you start at 6+ months, but as they get older they’ll get more and more independent. 
•
What if they find that dumping the cup is just super fun? Judy’s favorite trick is to put a coaster or sticker on their high chair tray and help them guide the cup back to the right spot. Make a “clink” sound when you put it down - they’ll want to repeat the sound.
•
It’s almost the weekend, friends! 💃💃💃💃

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'More likely to drink it: More likely to dump it everywhere: feedinglittles'.
Photo by Feeding Littles on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child and outdoors.
Photo by Feeding Littles on July 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and child.

Photo by Feeding Littles on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'SUMMER MEAL PLANNING EXPECTATIONS: REALITY: Monday Monday Caprese pasta salad roasted Spaghetti from-frozen meatballs broccoli fresh peaches salad roasted mixed veggies Tuesday Tuesday Shrimp tacos (cabbage, salsa, avocado)+ +beans+ watermelon Wednesday Crockpot pot roast+ roasted carrots mashed potatoes Thursday Chicken stir-fry (snow peas, bok choy, broccoli, peppers) rice Friday Veggie pizza fruit salad Leftovers Wednesday Something from the freezer Takeout Thursday Friday Grilledcheesefruit Cereal Saturday Dinner out with friends UGH Saturday Sunday BBQ night- turkey burgers, corn, grilled peppers/onions Sunday LITERALLY DON'T CARE FEND FOR YOURSELVES feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Let’s talk summertime cooking BURNOUT 😩🌞 - who’s totally sick of meal planning and cooking right now?
•
It’s hot. Kids are out of school. So many of us are mentally and emotionally depleted, and even though we know we need to eat - and of course are grateful to have anything on the table - everything is “blah” right now. I {Megan} always get to this point in the scorching Arizona heat 🌵🔥
•
What’s a tired parent {or any adult} to do? ➡️➡️ BE REALISTIC about what you can actually cook in a week. In my house, we make 3-4 “recipes” a week, max. The rest is spent eating leftovers, making “I Can’t Even” meals or enjoying restaurant food.
•
Nothing is worse than buying a bunch of fresh food, only to see it go bad in your fridge because you don’t have the capacity to make it. You may have wonderful intentions, but if you’re getting really sick of making food or you’re overwhelmed by life, a complicated meal may not be in the cards for you.
•
When you stock your kitchen with some super easy convenience foods like frozen pizza, bagged salad, frozen veggies, or pour and cook entrees, you’re less likely to waste food you don’t have the energy to make. Remember that breakfast for dinner, leftovers, sandwiches and snack plates are all great options too. {So is your favorite takeout joint 😉}
•
Need help? Head to our link in bio to nab our FREE Dinner Toolkit - it’s full of recipes but also tons of “I Can’t Even” dinner ideas!
•
If you’re struggling with your kiddo’s eating, don’t forget to check out our online courses at feedinglittles.com ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 27, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Having a picky eater doesn't mear you messed up. feedinglittles'.

node.text:
➡️ How your child eats is not a reflection of your parenting skills. Read it again: 📣📣📣 How your child eats is NOT a reflection of your parenting skills 📣📣📣
•
It’s so easy to get sucked into the social media comparison trap of “their kid will eat that, why won’t mine?” Have you ever felt this? 
•
Friends, our kids are all walking different paths in their development. How we parent doesn’t fully predict how they’ll turn out. When it comes to eating, there are actually SO many factors involved.
•
🤔 Did you know that it’s completely normal and expected for kids ages 12-24 months {sometimes earlier/later} to become suddenly more skeptical about food? To not want what they once loved?
•
🤔 Did you know that many kids only eat 2 decent meals a day, plus snacks? Many kids eat next to nothing for an entire meal each day and yet still manage to grow and thrive.
•
🤔 Did you know that feeding and nutrition professionals themselves have picky eaters or go through picky stages and it’s completely expected? {Megan’s daughter Mia is in a fun phase right now, lemme tell ya…🙄🙄🙄}
•
Sure, the environment you create and how you approach food/mealtime can make a difference - and that’s what we address here and in our online courses.
•
BUT…if your child is dealing with more, it’s might be time to get some expert help.
•
If you’re worried about your child’s eating or growth, bring it up with your provider. If they keep dropping foods they’ll eat, struggle with chewing/swallowing, eat fewer than 20 total foods, won’t touch certain textures, regularly gag at the sight of foods, have anxiety around foods or if you know in your gut that something feels off…talk to your doc. It might be time for an evaluation with an OT or SLP specializing in feeding.
•
And please, please go easy on yourself. You didn’t “ruin” them. It’s not “too late” for your kid to love all types of food one day. It’s such a process, and so many parents are in the thick of it with you 🙏
•
If you need more help, be sure to check out our online courses at feedinglittles.com ❤️

node.text:
Of course I don’t give my kids frozen nuggets…I cook them first 👊 via @kat_can_cook 
•
No matter what or how your family eats today or who makes the food in your family…enjoy it ❤️ Happy weekend!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 23, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Does your baby love to put ALL THE TEETHERS in their mouth - but not food? Try putting food on a {clean} teether - the familiarity of the teether may be just what they need to realize what to try and hopefully like food! Will you tag a friend who has a baby at home?
•
Foodie Judy here! When starting solids, my private clients and our clients here at @feedinglittles are SO excited. They’ve been waiting 6 months and they are looking forward to this fun, new experience with their baby. In some cases, though, baby wants nothing to do with food. They don’t get what all the excitement is about.
•
If your baby loves teethers, one technique I use is putting some food directly on a clean teether. This works well with silicone teethers that can be easily cleaned. A small amount of smashed avocado, banana, or oatmeal on a teether can be just what your baby needs to connect the dots. Once they get used to eating off their teether, you can try spoons like the @numnuminc GOOtensil or strips of soft food.
•
Other tips:
1. Eat with your baby! They need someone to imitate, and the more you eat together the more it will “click.”
2. We recommend starting with 1 meal a day around 6 months, but if your baby isn’t into it yet, bump up to 2-3 meals {exposures} per day. The more they experience food, the more likely they are to understand what to do with it. Some babies don’t really “get” feeding themselves until at least 7-8 months old.
3. Stay patient and positive. Don’t force them - some babies just need more practice and exposure. If you’re not seeing improvement after many weeks of daily practice, mention it to your provider. 
4. We have a bunch of additional troubleshooting tips in our Infant Course - definitely check out that section if you’re struggling!
•
Featured: @comotomobaby silicone baby teether, one of our top choices - check out our favorite teethers at our link in bio!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 22, 2021. May be an image of fruit and text that says 'FOODS I DON'T ENJOY: Beets Shrimp Olives FOODS I STILL SERVE το MY KIDS: Beets Shrimp Olives feedinglittles'.

node.text:
What foods do you suuuuuper dislike? Tell us ⬇️⬇️⬇️ We polled a few team members and beets, shrimp and olives came up as their least favorite foods.
 
Maybe your list of foods you won’t eat is pretty long. Maybe you struggle with picky eating as an adult, and you don’t want to pass on you dislikes to their kids. After all, if they know you won’t touch it, they’re less likely to eat it themselves.
•
Guess what? You can navigate this. Everyone has foods they like and dislike. We don’t HAVE to love every food on the planet. Here are some tips:
•
1) Serve the food you don’t like to your kids when you can. We easily write off foods we don’t enjoy, but when we don’t serve them our kids don’t learn to eat them either.
•
2) Model interacting with the food, even if you just pick it up and smell it. While you may not be ready to eat it {ever}, your child will see it on your plate and will know that you’re OK touching it. Side note: many of you have shared that our Toddler Course strategies have helped with your partner’s eating habits, or even your own! Sometimes these baby steps can help you learn to enjoy that food one day.
•
3) Keep language about the food neutral. You don’t have to lie to your kid and say you love it, but try to avoid saying you hate it. {Kids pick up on that so fast and won’t even touch the food.} Phrases like, “That’s not for me right now,” “I am really enjoying my strawberries,” or a simple “No thank you/not right now” are all great ways to politely decline food. Turning it back to your child can help too: “I’m eating my chicken right now, but I know how much you love those peas! Want to show me how many you can line up in a row?”
•
4) The goal is for our kids to eventually like most foods...but they won’t like every single thing on their plate. That’s OK! We want them to be able to identify the foods that they enjoy the most and that make them feel their best. As they get older they will realize that you don’t like or eat every food either. They may learn that they eat differently than their friends. Give them the opportunity to explore all types of food and try to keep mealtime positive, even if you’re not an adventurous eater yourself.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Feeding Littles on July 21, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'I'm glad I spent all this money on a high chair just for my kid to sit on my lap. feedinglittles'.

node.text:
Does your toddler LOVE sitting in your lap at mealtime? Yeah, it’s a thing. If you’re getting frustrated with it, here are some tips ⬇️⬇️⬇️

1️⃣ They may be craving connection with you, especially if you haven’t seen them all day. Remember that this phase is temporary {we promise!} and that they may just need physical touch and close proximity if they’re missing you. That’s ok! Cuddle your sweet babe and let them sit on your lap if it works for you. Try lots of cuddles and babywearing if their size permits before mealtime to ease the transition.
2️⃣ Perhaps their chair isn’t comfortable or conducive to supportive sitting. Click our link in bio to check out our Favorite High Chairs and Boosters post, where we talk about the importance of positioning at the table and how to make your child’s chair more supportive.
3️⃣ Sometimes sitting on your lap becomes habit - it could be time to shake up mealtime routines and start laying a new foundation. Try a carpet picnic or a change of scenery where your child has a chance to sit in their own spot. 
4️⃣ If you really need some personal space, sitting your child very close to you can help them feel secure and fulfill their need to be next to you. Slide their chair up close to yours so they know you’re nearby. It’s OK to say “I need my own space while we eat. Why don’t you sit right next to me and show me how you use your fork!”

Don’t forget that our Toddler Course is here to help you with frustrating mealtime behavior - check it out at feedinglittles.com ❤️❤️❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Feeding Littles on July 20, 2021 tagging @munchkininc, @numnuminc, @gerber, and @avanchyshop. May be an image of text that says 'feedinglittles "How can Ihelp my kid learn to use utensils?" Purchase forks and spoons that look and function like adult forks and spoons, just smaller. Once your child can use them, offer your "regular" family cutlery. Short handle Avanchy'.

node.text:
Let’s talk SILVERWARE {and how to help your kids use it eventually}! Tag a friend with a baby or toddler at home who could use some tips!
•
Judy here! 👋 I am an OT Feeding Therapist, and one thing I recommend with silverware is that it’s so important to ➡️keep it small and ➡️keep it simple. You do not need to invest in a bunch of different types of spoons and forks, and interestingly, the products we recommend for infants can be used well into toddlerhood – no need to have multiple types for multiple ages if you don’t want to. Just remember:
☑️Short, wide handle
☑️Looks and functions like a real fork or spoon
☑️Can hold onto food well
•
Our Amazon shop is full of our favorite utensils!
•
You can also use “real” spoons and forks with young children – just be careful with sharp tines on forks.
•
How can I help them use utensils?
1) Touching food with their hands and messy exploration at mealtime is still #1.
2) Starting at 6 months, also offer loaded utensils to your child. They need practice to learn, but every kiddo will do this differently. It’s not a race - it’s a process ❤️
3) We don’t expect most toddlers to independently use utensils {scooping with a spoon, stabbing food with a fork} until closer to 16-18 months if they have been practicing regularly. If they need more help, try the activities in the chart {swipe through} and work with your provider.
4) Never force your child to use utensils. It’s ok for them to default to their hands.
•
If you’re doing those things, you’re well on your way to successful utensil usage 🙌 Just remember, EVERY KIDDO IS DIFFERENT ❤️
•
What if my child always defaults to using their hands? ➡️➡️ The biggest issue is - CAN they use utensils? Are they using their hands for other tasks even if they put down the fork at mealtime? Are they using their hands in their daily play? If the answer is yes, we generally don’t worry about utensil use as long as your child is *able* to use them and shows progression toward more coordinated use of their hands as they get older.
•
Need more help feeding your baby or toddler? Head to feedinglittles.com to check out our online courses!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Feeding Littles on July 20, 2021 tagging @munchkininc, @numnuminc, @gerber, and @avanchyshop. May be an image of text that says 'feedinglittles "How can Ihelp my kid learn to use utensils?" Purchase forks and spoons that look and function like adult forks and spoons, just smaller. Once your child can use them, offer your "regular" family cutlery. Short handle Avanchy'.
Photo by Feeding Littles on July 20, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
WEIRD THINGS KIDS DO WITH UTENSILS 🍴🥄 {that are completely “normal” and expected}!
•
Friends, tomorrow we will share all our tips and techniques for helping your child learn to use forks and spoons…but today, let’s celebrate the funny things kids do as they are learning! Does your kid do any of these?
•
Toddlers want so badly to “DO MYSELF.” They watch you use your fork like a pro and try their hardest to do it too, even if they have a few hiccups along the way. It’s super common for them to:
➕Hold a spoon in one hand, eat with the other
➕Use the wrong end of the utensil
➕Pull food off their fork and eat it…instead of just putting the fork in their mouth 🙈
➕Not let you help them use utensils
➕Steal your fork {we recommend letting them use yours as long as it’s not too sharp!}
➕Default back to using their hands - it’s just easier sometimes!
•
What can you do? Let them continue to explore and practice 👊 Check back tomorrow for more tips by age that can help them become utensil pros!
•
Don’t forget that our online courses for babies and toddlers/kids are here to help! Get pro tips from feeding experts, right at home! Feedinglittles.com 👊
